Lewis Stein

statement + vita

statement

I have worked without attachment to any program whether political, social psychological or aesthetic and without attachment to craft. Nevertheless, certain concerns run through what has been a very diverse production:

  1. A concern with perception – seeing the function of art practice as a means of becoming aware of the world in ways previously not realized and seeing the function of the art object as a vehicle to communicate (by embodying) these insights. The concern with perception is never detached or disembodied and is almost always connected to a social (e.g. "Surveillance Series"), cultural (eg. Object pieces), or psychological context (e.g. "Candid Portraits").
  2. A concern with making manifest structural aspects of various media that are usually taken for granted. E.g. "early painting" were in essence a deconstruction of painting; "Light Series" where light, the medium that makes photography possible by reflecting off of the various scenes photographed is instead made the subject of the work.
  3. A concern with making work which speaks directly to the viewer or forms a transactional relationship with the viewer (as opposed to work that ultimately functions as an object the be analyzed or understood or to infer sensibility from). In other words a focus less on the object and more on the space between the viewer (participant) and the object; that is, a focus on the way meaning is generated.

Almost all the work I have done embodies one or more of the above concerns.
